list_definition.definition: to lessen or stop (pain, worry etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The doctor gave him some drugs to relieve the pain
Aid is being sent to relieve the hardship of the refugees.

list_definition.definition: to take over a job or task from

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: You guard the door first, and I’ll relieve you in two hours.

list_definition.definition: to dismiss (a person) from his job or position

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He was relieved of his post/duties.

list_definition.definition: to take (something heavy, difficult etc) from someone

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: May I relieve you of that heavy case?
The new gardener relieved the old man of the burden of cutting the grass.

list_definition.definition: to come to the help of (a town etc which is under siege or attack).

list_ex_of_english: Besides, poverty may diminish his importance in the eyes of his parishioners, especially if he cannot relieve them in their distress.
In the setting of cancer, physical distress needs to be relieved before psychological or existential suffering can be attended to.
The left lateral position can improve fetal blood -ow by relieving aortocaval compression.
Indeed, given a physician's obligation to relieve a patient's pain, such acts are at times obligatory.
It is instituted not to end life, but to relieve suffering.
Current priorities for research and research funding re-ect a strongly felt need, among governments and donor agencies, for rapid problem-solving to relieve poverty.
The first three months of 1842 alone saw them relieving over 10,000 casuals, at a cost of nearly £2,000.
This is a highly desirable feature that relieves the burden of coding missions in agent systems from the start.
